questions.text: I have survived by:

options.text: Refusing to admit or fully acknowledge certain emotions or realities, even when they were clear to others.

questions.text: I have survived by:

options.text: Avoiding situations, people, or emotions that feel too uncomfortable or difficult to handle.

questions.text: I have survived by:

options.text: Frequently pointing out flaws or faults in others to avoid looking at or confronting my own insecurities.

questions.text: I have survived by:

options.text: Harshly judging or belittling myself to avoid facing deeper emotional pain or fear of not being enough.

questions.text: I have survived by:

options.text: Pushing uncomfortable thoughts or emotions out of my awareness to avoid dealing with them.

questions.text: I have survived by:

options.text: Noticing feelings or behaviors in others that may actually reflect something within me.

questions.text: I have survived by:

options.text: Redirecting my emotions, like frustration or anger, toward something or someone unrelated.

questions.text: I have survived by:

options.text: Explaining or justifying my actions with logical reasons, even when the real reason might be uncomfortable to face.

questions.text: I have survived by:

options.text: Channeling intense emotions into creative projects, hobbies, or physical activities.

questions.text: I have survived by:

options.text: Falling back into behaviors or habits that remind me of how I handled stress as a child.

questions.text: I have survived by:

options.text: Focusing on facts, logic, or analysis to avoid fully engaging with difficult emotions.

questions.text: I have survived by:

options.text: Acting in ways that are the opposite of how I truly feel in order to protect myself or others.

questions.text: Regarding touch:

options.text: I rarely notice sensations like fabric on my skin, or I often don’t register temperature changes until they are extreme.
I sometimes notice sensations but don’t always feel them in the moment (e.g., brushing against something).
I’m often very aware of the way fabric or textures feel against my skin and can notice temperature changes easily.
I am highly sensitive to touch and temperature, often feeling every change, even subtle ones.

questions.text: How aware are you of your internal body signals (hunger, thirst, fatigue, etc.)?

options.text: I rarely notice my body’s signals until they become intense or overwhelming.
I’m sometimes aware of internal signals, but I often miss them until they escalate.
I can usually sense my body’s needs (hunger, rest) when they are moderate.
I am acutely aware of my body’s needs, even subtle ones, and respond promptly.

questions.text: How aware are you of your body’s position in space (e.g., when walking or moving)?

options.text: I often feel “disconnected” from my body’s movements, sometimes bumping into things without noticing.
I am occasionally aware of my body position but tend to lose track when I’m distracted.
I feel pretty grounded and aware of my body’s movements, noticing when I shift position.
I have a strong sense of my body’s position and movements, even when I’m engaged in other tasks.

questions.text: When entering new spaces or situations:

options.text: I rarely feel any sense of discomfort or “alertness,” even in unfamiliar environments.
I feel some level of awareness when entering new spaces but it’s usually mild.
I often scan my environment for potential threats or shifts in safety, noticing subtle cues.
I am hyper-aware of potential threats and feel an immediate response to shifts in my environment, even if they are small.

questions.text: When problem-solving or stressed, where do you focus your attention?

options.text: Only in my head (thoughts, ideas)
Entirely in my body (physical sensations, feelings)

questions.text: When in pain or discomfort, how do you usually respond?

options.text: Ignore it and push through
Explore the sensation to understand it better

questions.text: How often do you feel 'in your body' vs 'in your head'?

options.text: Rarely or never in my body
Fully grounded in my body most of the time

questions.text: Comfort exploring sensations without judgment?

options.text: Not at all / Rarely
Often / Always

questions.text: Ease describing body sensations to someone else?

options.text: Very difficult / Difficult
Easy / Very easy

questions.text: Rely on logic or trust your gut when deciding?

options.text: Rely on logic or outside advice
Often trust gut feelings or physical instincts

questions.text: React to discomfort with distraction or presence?

options.text: Distract with activities like working or scrolling
Stay present with my body even when uncomfortable

questions.text: Check any conditions you have been diagnosed with or experienced:

options.text: Anxiety Disorders (e.g., GAD, panic disorder, social anxiety)

questions.text: Check any conditions you have been diagnosed with or experienced:

options.text: Hypermobility / Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome

questions.text: Check any conditions you have been diagnosed with or experienced:

options.text: Hyperthyroidism or Hypothyroidism

questions.text: Check any conditions you have been diagnosed with or experienced:

options.text: Depression (e.g., major depressive disorder, dysthymia)

questions.text: Check any conditions you have been diagnosed with or experienced:

options.text: PTSD or Complex PTSD

questions.text: Check any conditions you have been diagnosed with or experienced:

options.text: ADHD or Autism Spectrum

questions.text: Check any conditions you have been diagnosed with or experienced:

options.text: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome / ME

questions.text: Check any conditions you have been diagnosed with or experienced:

options.text: Fibromyalgia

questions.text: Check any conditions you have been diagnosed with or experienced:

options.text: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)

questions.text: Check any conditions you have been diagnosed with or experienced:

options.text: Dysautonomia (e.g., POTS, orthostatic hypotension)

questions.text: Check any conditions you have been diagnosed with or experienced:

options.text: Long Covid / Post-viral Syndrome

questions.text: How does your body feel when you wake up?

options.text: Stiff, like I’ve been braced all night.
Restless, like I didn’t fully relax during sleep.
Heavy or sluggish, like it’s hard to get moving.
Refreshed and ready to start the day.

questions.text: What do you notice about your body when you’re sitting?

options.text: I feel myself bracing or holding tension in my core or back.
I shift positions often or feel the need to move frequently.
I slouch or feel my body collapsing into the chair.
I sit with ease and feel supported by my posture.

questions.text: When you’re doing physical activity, what feels true?

options.text: I over-engage my muscles, feeling tense or rigid.
I move quickly or find it hard to slow down.
I feel sluggish or disconnected from the activity.
I feel aligned and connected to my movements.

questions.text: What do you notice about your hands during the day?

options.text: My hands often feel clenched, like they’re ready to grip something.
I fidget with objects or move my fingers often without realizing it.
My hands feel limp or heavy, like they lack energy.
My hands feel relaxed, and I only use them when needed.

questions.text: How do you use your hands when expressing yourself?

options.text: I use sharp, forceful gestures or make fists without noticing.
My gestures are quick, and I find myself using my hands a lot.
My movements are slow, or I avoid using my hands when speaking.
My hand gestures feel natural and flow with my speech.

questions.text: What do you notice about your jaw during the day?

options.text: My jaw feels tight, clenched, or overactive.
I catch myself grinding my teeth or moving my jaw frequently.
My jaw feels slack, heavy, or disconnected.
My jaw feels relaxed and balanced.

questions.text: When you’re thinking or stressed, what do you notice about your mouth?

options.text: I press my lips together tightly or clench my teeth.
I chew on things (e.g., pens, nails) or move my mouth restlessly.
My mouth feels dry or sluggish, and I avoid speaking.
My mouth feels comfortable and ready to engage when I need to.

questions.text: How do your eyes feel during the day?

options.text: I often squint, even when I don’t need to.
I find myself looking away or avoiding eye contact.
My vision feels blurry or unfocused at times, even without a medical issue.
I feel comfortable and open making eye contact.

questions.text: What do you notice about your gaze in social situations?

options.text: My gaze feels sharp or intense, like I’m on high alert.
I tend to look around or scan the room frequently.
I feel my eyes drooping or avoiding looking at others.
I can maintain eye contact naturally without effort.

questions.text: How does your head feel in relation to your posture?

options.text: I often feel my head pushing forward or craning out.
I find myself turning my head frequently or avoiding holding it still.
My head feels heavy, like it’s being pulled down.
My head feels balanced on my shoulders.

questions.text: What do you notice in your shoulders?

options.text: My shoulders often feel tight or braced, like I’m ready to act.
I shrug or move my shoulders often without realizing it.
My shoulders feel drooped or collapsed inward.
My shoulders feel relaxed and aligned.

questions.text: How would you describe your walking or standing posture?

options.text: I tend to walk or stand with a stiff or rigid posture.
I feel light on my feet, almost like I’m avoiding the ground.
I feel heavy, like I’m sinking into the ground.
I feel grounded and steady when I walk or stand.

questions.text: When you sit or stand for long periods, how does your body react?

options.text: My legs feel tense, as if they’re ready to move at any moment.
I find myself fidgeting or needing to adjust often.
My lower body feels numb or disconnected.
My posture feels natural, and I can stay comfortable.

questions.text: How does your breathing feel most of the time?

options.text: Deep, forceful, or labored, like I’m preparing for action or bracing myself.
Quick and uneven, often tied to feeling rushed or restless.
Shallow and slow, as if I’m stuck or holding back.
Deep and steady, with a sense of ease and balance.

questions.text: When you’re under stress, how does your breathing change?

options.text: It becomes tight or high in my chest, like the air is stuck in my throat.
It speeds up and feels shallow, like I’m struggling to catch my breath.
It feels like I stop breathing or hold my breath.
It stays steady, even under pressure.

questions.text: What position do you typically sleep in?

options.text: Tense or curled up, like I’m protecting myself.
Restless, frequently changing positions.
Heavy and still, almost like I’m stuck in one position.
Relaxed and natural, with ease to adjust if needed.
